awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Microencapsulation-based genomics of individual RNA viruses
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is an outgrowth of a project previously funded by OTIC to develop a method for environment micro-compartment genomics (EMCG) of DNA particles and if this method is successful for RNA, it has potential important applications not only in marine RNA virus research but also in public health and epidemiology. Current methods are not sensitive enough to detect small RNA viruses making quantification of RNA viruses in marine samples difficult. Methods for direct quantification are needed to verify the numbers in marine habitats. RNA viruses and virus-like particles in the ocean, play a major role in microbial ecology and evolution. The ability to analyses of individual RNA viruses would potentially be transformative in oceanography as well as public health and epidemiology. As a result of this Bigelow Laboratory’s Single Cell Genomics Center (SCGC) would provide this analysis as a service to the global research community. The PI’s will also mentor an undergraduate student and provide advanced courses Bioinformatics of Microbial Single Cells and Aquatic Flow Cytometry.

The role of RNA viruses is even less understood than those of DNA-containing extracellular genetic elements, due to technical challenges. The PIs have previous OTIC funding to develop environment micro-compartment genomics (EMCG) of DNA particles Early results of this project suggests that a modification of the EMCG methods may enable genomic sequencing of both DNA and RNA particles, thus addressing this pressing need. The PIs request EAGER funding to develop a novel, microencapsulation-based technology for whole genome sequencing of RNA viruses from the ocean, with potential applications in other environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit. Viruses and other extracellular particles are ubiquitous in the ocean and other environments, but their numbers, composition, and roles remain poorly understood due to technical challenges. In particular, the de novo assembly and binning of genomic reads from bulk RNA and DNA extracts, although useful, are not capable of resolving most of the viral diversity in the ocean. Even in the context of public health, the COVID-19 pandemic has underscored the importance of and challenges in tracking genome-level diversity and the evolution of pathogenic viruses. The contemporary methods for the genomics of COVID-19 and other viruses rely on the sequencing and assembly of bulk extracts of nucleic acids, which have a limited capacity for reliably tracking genome rearrangements and linkages among mutations. This project aimed to help address this challenge by developing technology for quantitative genome analyses of individual extracellular RNA particles, such as RNA viruses. With this grant’s support, we established robust protocols for massively parallel encapsulation and sequencing of extracellular genetic elements, including combinatorial barcoding inside semipermeable capsules (SPCs), enabling a 10x increase in analytical throughput and a similar reduction in associated costs – a transformative development for studies of extracellular elements. A major, unexpected discovery of this work was that viruses with non-canonical DNA are abundant in the ocean and are invisible to the conventional metagenomic methods of viral research.

Broader impacts. We anticipate that technology developed with the support of this grant will be transformative not only in oceanography but also in public health and epidemiology, including improved tracking of genome-level diversity and the evolution of pathogenic viruses. We have already started offering genomic sequencing of individual viruses and other extracellular genetic elements as services to the global research community through the Bigelow Laboratory’s Single Cell Genomics Center (SCGC), ensuring a sustainable continuation of this technology investment. Furthermore, a non-provisional patent application has been filed to enhance the commercialization potential of this technology. This project has also contributed to workforce development by providing advanced training in microfluidics, DNA sequencing, and bioinformatics for five professionals (postdoctoral researchers, bioinformaticians, and research associates). It has also augmented courses in aquatic flow cytometry and the bioinformatics of single microbial cells. The results of this project were disseminated through five scientific presentations and one Café Scientifique presentation to the general public.
